person.note: See note on other entry for Sérapion.

author.note: Bishop of Iconium connected with the Cappadocian Fathers. Syriac translations of works attributed to him include an encomium on Basil, and a hagiographic work about Athanasius of Alexandria.

bibl.title: Geschichte der syrischen Literatur
Acta martyrum et sanctorum
Gewargis I
The Gorgias Encyclopedic Dictionary of the Syriac Heritage
The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium

person.note: Should we assume this is pseudonymous, like the works about Basil attributed to Amphilochius?

author.note: The servant of a George who was martyred with Antony the Soldier and Alexandra the Queen. He is the purported author of the work describing that martyrdom.

bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

person.note: Zanetti just had this as a regular author but Wright (3:1119) says it "pretends to be written by Pasicrates." Should we use "attributed" or "pseudo"?

author.note: Bishop of Constantinople (406-425) and author of a homily on the Virgin Mary extant in Syriac

bibl.title: Proclus of Constantinople
The Gorgias Encyclopedic Dictionary of the Syriac Heritage
A Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Christianity
The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium
Une homélie inédite d’Atticus patriarche de Constantinople (406-425)
Revue de l'Orient Chrêtien

author.note: The author of a text about Catholicos Denḥa I. Chabot (see bibliography below) possibly his secretary, and infers his name to be ܝܘܚܢܢ (Jean) on the basis of a kind of anagram in his text.

bibl.title: Éloge du patriarche nestorien Mar Denha Ier par le moine Jean
Journal asiatique

author.note: A disciple of Dioscorus of Alexandria and the purported author of his biography.

bibl.title: Histoire de Dioscore, patriarche d’Alexandrie, écrite par son disciple Théopiste
Journal asiatique

author.note: The author of a hagiographic work about the saint Sāhdā Marī d-Bēth-Sāhdē.

person.note: Should we handle this this way or with type="pseudo"?
Other works of Amphiloque are of questionable authenticity. I haven't been able to find out more about this one, so for now, I've put "attributed".

author.note: Theologian and author of numerous Greek works, of which The Monks of Sinai survives in a Syriac version.

bibl.title: The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium

person.note: Khamis is attributed (see, e.g., Wright, Cambridge, 1:162), but what @type should we put on the author?

author.note: A monk to whom is attributed a work about the Virgin Mary

person.note: Is this an OK way to mark two possible but uncertain authors /person/42 and the monk Phocas of Gagim also know as Malke etc. See: https://archive.org/stream/MinganaCatalogueOfTheMinganaCollection.I/Mingana_Catalogue%20of%20the%20Mingana%20Collection.I#page/n467/mode/2up "Jacob" is attributed in Ms. Borg. sir. 128 f. 78v. (http://digi.vatlib.it/view/MSS_Borg.sir.128/0160)

bibl.title: Catalogue of the Mingana Collection of Manuscripts

author.persName: GRYGWRY of Reshʿaina, disciple of Sophronios
Gregorios from Reshʿaina, a disciple of Sophronios, the bishop of Jerusalem
author.note: Author of a work about his contemporary Maximus the Confessor (d. 662), and a bishop under Sophronios of Jerusalem (r. 634-638). The manuscript witness (BM Add. 7192, ff. 72b-78b) gives his name as both Gewargis and Gregorios, one of which is likely a scribal error.

Brock tentatively suggests the identification of this George with the author of an apparently monothelete Chalcedonian florilegium contained in BM Add. 14535 ff. 1-20. He considers it unlikely that this author was late enough to be identified with the George present at the Sixth Council (680/681).
author.death: after the death of Maximus the Confessor (662)

bibl.title: An Early Syriac Life of Maximus the Confessor
Analecta Bollandiana

person.note: Do we need URIs for either the haṣya George or the George at the sixth council? See notes above. Also, how can we label his confession as Chalcedonian monothelete?

author.note: Pseudonymous 5th century (or later) Armenian author of the life of Gregory the Illuminator

bibl.title: A Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Christianity
The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium

person.note:
I think this record is ready now.
Agathange/Agathangelos was the author -- the name of the abbreviator is not given so far as I can tell. Nor is Agathange's name given in Syriac at the beginning or end of the work.
This is an interesting challenge, besides pseudo we need continuator and abbreviator? Can you get: van Esbroeck, M. 1977.“Le résumé syriaque de l'Agathange.” AB 95: 291–358 (esp. 292). Pg. 292 says "Rappelons brièvement que diverse détails de cette forme de l'Agathange rendent son éclosion probable entre les années 604 à 610" Should we just use "editor" element with @type="abbreviator"?

author.note: Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia; successor and biographer of Basil of Caesarea

person.note: Is Zanetti's "Shemkha" really a spelling we should keep? E.g., Scher spells it "Schemcha"

Checking with J-N about this:
There are 2 texts (http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/work/1728 and http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/work/1031) about Mark the Hermit of Tarmaqa, whom I take to be this Marqos (http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/1356, fl. 4th cent.). These stories are said to be narrated by an Abba Serapion the monk while he was in the Egyptian desert/interior of Scetis. I can’t seem to find out more information about this Serapion. Is he the same as http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2065 and/or http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2067? (These two look to me like they are probably the same, whereas the Serapion here http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2066 from a group of martyrs looks different.)

author.note: A 7th-cent. historian whose work is quoted in the Chronicle of Siirt

person.note: Seems to be the same as 917, described in Baumstark, 135? Since this is a text about the martyrs, does this refer to the same "Bar Sahde" mentioned in GEDSH, or is it a name related to the martyrdoms?
At most this should be an "attribution." But Wright's catalogue doesn't even say Isaac for this work. So remove author altogether?
Is @type="pseudo" an OK way to handle "Pseudo-Méthode d’Olympe"?

person.note: Is editor @type="scribe" OK for "Marin et Anatole, excepteurs"? Actually, Marinus and Anatolius are mentioned as "notaries" who wrote down the account for Edessa's archive (https://archive.org/stream/ancientsyriacdo00wriggoog#page/n82/mode/2up). So should they be recorded as scribes?

person.note:
Which editor @type should we use?
Nau says that Zachariah "prononcé" the original Coptic or Arabic version (https://archive.org/stream/revuedelorientch171912pari#page/348/mode/2up), whereas Wright takes the note at the beginning of the text to mean Zachariah was the translator (3:1115). However, the Syriac could mean "explain," etc. Include in abstract once we've decided how to handle this.
